newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: FOCUS-Mahathir calm on ringgit, taunts speculators.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Mahathir calm on ringgit, taunts speculators.

text.p: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Saturday he was confident of overcoming a crisis in the ringgit after the currency fell to its worst level this week.
"We are quite confident of managing our economy," he told a news conference.
Mahathir, who has always maintained that Malaysia's economic fundamentals were strong enough to survive any crisis, admitted that the instability of the ringgit was a problem.
"If you asked me whether I'm happy with the level of the ringgit, of course I'm not happy," he said. "I want it to go back."
Fresh speculative selling pushed the ringgit to 2.8250 to the dollar on Friday, its weakest level since it was officially floated in 1973.
But the ringgit staged a sharp recovery to 2.7780 before the end of the day.
Mahathir said the country would ride out speculative attacks on the currency.
"Well, they can hammer (the ringgit) as much they like but we will come out of it somehow," he said.
However, foreign exchange dealers and analysts said the worst may not be over for the ringgit as Southeast Asian currencies remain under pressure.

The ringgit, like the Thai baht, the Philippine peso and the Indonesian rupiah, has been hit by speculative attacks and a rush by local companies to hedge foreign borrowings over the past month, losing nearly 13 percent of its value.
The ringgit was around 2.50 against the dollar before it sank along with the baht, rupiah and peso last month. A year ago, it was at 2.49.
Mahathir was reported earlier this week as saying that Malaysia planned to reduce imports and review the implementation of some large projects to manage the currency losses.
"We are not suspending anything because they are private sector projects that will go on," he said on Saturday, adding that his call for a "slowdown" should not be misinterpreted as a freeze.

Fast-growing Malaysia has several huge infrastructure projects under construction such as the 13.6 billion ringgit ($4.9 billion) Bakun hydro-electric dam and the nine billion ringgit new Kuala Lumpur International Airport.
